We must “build” a simplified “trial‐balance” of our very many transactions that affect only the current assets. (For example, the “initial” records include a cash deposit, a bank deposit and – though there is also a fixed assets record – fixed assets do not count as part of current assets.) Then we “simulate” the posting of every transaction that affects a current asset account (namely cash, bank deposits and (interest or customer) receivables) while ignoring transactions that have no immediate cash/receivable effect (for example, fixed asset acquisitions, depreciation, or purchases/events recorded “on‐account”).

Below is an outline of how we can “simulate” the posts:

1. The “initial” current assets (the ones that count toward current assets) are given by:

  • Cash deposit = 3,000,000.00 
  • Bank deposit = 5,000,000.00 
  • (Fixed assets are not included.)

Thus the Total Current Assets at “initial” is 3,000,000 + 5,000,000 = 8,000,000.00

2. Then for each subsequent transaction that “moves” cash or bank funds or creates – or later collects – a receivable, we add or subtract the transaction’s amount according to whether it produces a receipt (increase) or an outlay (decrease) in one of the following accounts:
  – Cash (if payment method = “Cash”)
  – Bank (if payment method = “Bank Transfer”)
  – “Receivables” (if a sale is made on “Account Receivable”)
  – “Interest receivables” (for the interest transactions)

(For purchases or expenses paid “on-hand” the cash or bank balance decreases, for sales with “Paid” status the cash or bank balance increases, and “unpaid” sales “on account” add into receivables. … Transfers between cash and bank do not change the overall total.)

3. After “posting” every one of the items (a rather long simulation – see the detailed “step‐by‐step simulation” explanation above), the “final balances” in our simplified trial balance came out roughly as follows:

  • Cash ~ 1,254,763.92  
  • Bank ~ 2,244,400.00  
  • Receivables (from sales on account) ~ 335,967.05  
  • Interest receivables ~ 7,775.44

Thus the Total (ending) current assets equals:  
  1,254,763.92 + 2,244,400.00 + 335,967.05 + 7,775.44 ≈ 3,842,906.41

4. Hence the answer is:

• Total Current Assets Initial Value = 8,000,000.00  
• Total Current Assets End Value = 3,842,906.41

Note: In an exam or actual accounting system one would “post” every transaction entry via an accounting system. Here we “simulate” the overall effect on the current asset–related account balances (cash, bank, receivables and interest receivables) while ignoring those entries not “current” (like fixed assets, depreciation, etc).
